replies.msg:
I know how that feel bro... so9sad

I worked in HA for a little bit more than 10 years, and I post a few post just saying HA clerical job is not worse in HK, still being accused by young people that I am 'hitman' from HA... kind of irony.

From my personal point of view, compare with private company, HA in these recent year management direction is very similar to private companies, however, the organization is under public sector separate from Government, it still has a lot of government shadow which is a double edge sword. One good thing is salary increment will follow government, and the opposite side will be when in good economy it will show employee salary increment below economic growth.

This applies to all for / against factor for any HA staff.

I don't want to try to add anything to say HA clerical job is a perfect job, and in fact, there will be no perfect job in this world. Search a perfect job is impossible, rather try to think if HA clerical job is the ideal job for candidate current situation in terms of academic qualification, previous job experience, job technique he/she already acquired. Most important of all, promotion opportunities.

As for sick leave issue, as long as employee can present a clinic attendance record, the day-off will consider as sick leave and no annual leave will be deducted, which is a very common HR practice. Unless, new generation of employee simply like a day off without prior notice. As myself as an example, I will notify my superior 1 month before I take an annual leave and every year I will discuss with him which month I will take annual leave more than 7 days so that he will be well aware all teammates schedule. It is all planning and communication and I do believe that all U-grad should know that much better than I since most them already had experience in different society in their U-life, I hope which I don't.

An old saying 'Fortune favors bold, fortune favors brave.' There is nothing wrong young people don't want to get HA offer, on the other hand, there are too many people who really need a stable, annual increment, permanent job that can support themselves and their family living.

Afterall, no matter what post you are in HA, whatever good thing you did, you are really serving patients / citizen of Hong Kong, a city we should be proud of, no matter how bad it became.

From my personal point of view, compare with private company, HA in these recent year management direction is very similar to private companies, however, the organization is under public sector separate from Government, it still has a lot of government shadow which is a double edge sword. One good thing is salary increment will follow government, and the opposite side will be when in good economy it will show employee salary increment below economic growth.

This applies to all for / against factor for any HA staff.

I don't want to try to add anything to say HA clerical job is a perfect job, and in fact, there will be no perfect job in this world. Search a perfect job is impossible, rather try to think if HA clerical job is the ideal job for candidate current situation in terms of academic qualification, previous job experience, job technique he/she already acquired. Most important of all, promotion opportunities.

As for sick leave issue, as long as employee can present a clinic attendance record, the day-off will consider as sick leave and no annual leave will be deducted, which is a very common HR practice. Unless, new generation of employee simply like a day off without prior notice. As myself as an example, I will notify my superior 1 month before I take an annual leave and every year I will discuss with him which month I will take annual leave more than 7 days so that he will be well aware all teammates schedule. It is all planning and communication and I do believe that all U-grad should know that much better than I since most them already had experience in different society in their U-life, I hope which I don't.

An old saying 'Fortune favors bold, fortune favors brave.' There is nothing wrong young people don't want to get HA offer, on the other hand, there are too many people who really need a stable, annual increment, permanent job that can support themselves and their family living.

Afterall, no matter what post you are in HA, whatever good thing you did, you are really serving patients / citizen of Hong Kong, a city we should be proud of, no matter how bad it became.
